Award.AwardTitle: Transfer Hydrogenation: A Paradigm for Reversible Electrocatalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program, Professor Robert M. Waymouth of Stanford University will develop electrocatalysts for electrodehydrogenation of alcohols. Specific challenges for investigation are electrooxidation of alcohols at low overpotentials to maximize the energy efficiency of anode electrooxidation catalysts. A central hypothesis guiding this program is that transition metal catalysts active for the reversible transfer hydrogenation of ketones with alcohols constitute promising candidates for alcohol electrodehydrogenation catalysts. Catalysts which mediate reversible transfer hydrogenation reactions operate at the reversible potential for alcohol oxidation; a grand challenge is to exploit this promising reactivity to develop new electrocatalysts for reversible electrooxidation. Mechanistic concepts that have been developed for chemical transfer hydrogenation catalysis will be used to guide the research and to devise new strategies to facilitate the proton and electron transfers that are critical to energy-efficient electrooxidation catalysis.

The energy-efficient conversion of chemical fuels into useful forms of energy is critical to our energy future. This work will provide new insights on strategies for extracting electrons from chemical fuels and the fundamental science that underlies anode electrocatalysts for fuel cells that convert chemical energy into electricity. Discoveries from this research will illuminate key principles in mediating the energy efficient conversion of chemical energy into useful forms of electrical energy. These new insights will not only inform the quest for more efficient fuel cell catalysts, but are central to all technologies that mediate the interconversion of electrical energy and chemical energy. In addition, the PI will contribute to develop a new generation of scientists with expertise in this economically relevant field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposal by Professor Robert M. Waymouth of Stanford University was to develop new strategies for the reversible electrodehydrogenation of alcohols.  This proposal was funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of NSF's Chemistry Division (NSF-CHE 1213403).   The scientific objectives were closely integrated with training and education. Students were encouraged to embrace an interdisciplinary scientific approach to devise new experimental and theoretical approaches, both on their own and through collaborative interactions, to address the central hypothesis of this project:  That the thermoneutrality of transfer-hydrogenation reactions provides a useful paradigm for discovery of reversible electrodehydrogenation catalysts.

            This project focused on two interrelated intellectual activities: (1) the synthesis and evaluation of homogeneous and heterogeneous transfer hydrogenation catalysts that mediate the reversible exhange of hydrogen between alcohols and ketones, and (2) the development of electrodehdrogenation catalysts using design principles developed from these transfer hydrogenation catalysts. One significant outcome of the project was the discovery that both homogeneous and transfer hydrogenation catalysts can function as catalysts for the electrochemical dehydrogenation of alcohols, including both methanol and higher alcohols (isopropanol and ethanol). Nevertheless, kinetic and electrochemical experiments revealed that in some cases the electrochemical dehydrogenation of alcohols operate by a different mechanism than the transfer hydrogenation reactions, and mediate the electrooxidation of alcohols at higher potentials than the reversible potential for the electrooxidation of alcohols to ketones.  Synthetic and mechanistic studies were coupled with DFT calculations to provide design principles to develop more energy efficient electrocatalysts that can operate at lower overpotentials.  Additional significant outcomes included the discovery of new classes of transfer hydrogenation catalysts based on molybdenum, and new families of coordination complexes that undergo multiple electron transfers at constant potential. 

            Broader impacts the project include a new scientific insights on electrocatalysis, new strategies for efficient electrooxidation of chemical fuels, and an enhanced experimental and educational infrastructure for energy science.  This program provided an outstanding opportunity for educating the next generation of scientists. In the course of this project, students were able to acquire the intellectual and experimental expertise to address a broad range of research challenges in homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis, electrochemistry and electrocatalysis.  This expertise included the design and fabrication of new electrochemical cells and electroanalytical equipment, the synthesis of new families of coordination compounds and modified electrodes and the application of these complexes and modified electrodes to create new families of electrocatalysts.   Two female students received their Ph.D.s,and one female received her Masters Degree during the course of the grant.


Last Modified: 07/08/2016
Modified by: Robert M Waymouth
